item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
Both PIVOT and SSRS matrix have their place. However, there is a reason we have reporting methods and TSQL methods. In my own experience and something I try to relay down to everyone is, SSRS is good at doing what it is suppose to do. This goes for any reporting solution. TSQL is performs best doing what it does best in returning result sets and PIVOT almost crosses the line on that. Performance of a PIVOT action vs SSRS handling the tasks it is built to do is the absolute decision that must be made. Again, in my experience with the two, SSRS will pivot/cross tab etc.. the data given a fine tuned SQL statement behind it much faster than the PIVOT can handle.

This can also be said in regards so many of the newer functions that TSQL has added.

So essentially, no, it wouldn’t make more sense because it depends. And I’d put my money on SSRS outperforming PIVOT pretty much any day of the week üôÇ

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
Nice post

can you tell me what happens when you change your WHERE clause from this

WHERE CONVERT(DATETIME,CONVERT(VARCHAR(10),hdr.[OrderDate],121))>=CONVERT(DATETIME, CONVERT(VARCHAR(10), DATEADD(mm,-3,DATEADD(DAY,DAY(@today)*-1,@today+1)), 120), 120)
and CONVERT(DATETIME,CONVERT(VARCHAR(10),hdr.[OrderDate],121))<=CONVERT(DATETIME, CONVERT(VARCHAR(10), DATEADD(mm,0,@today – DAY(@today)), 120), 120)

TO this?

WHERE hdr.[OrderDate] >= DATEADD(qq, DATEDIFF(qq, 0, @today)-1, 0)
and hdr.[OrderDate] < DATEADD(qq, DATEDIFF(qq, 0, @today)+0, 0)

This way you don’t need to convert the hdr.[OrderDate] column

to see how it works run this

DECLARE @today DATETIME
SET @today=’2004-07-01 00:00:00.000′

SELECT DATEADD(qq, DATEDIFF(qq, 0, @today)-1, 0) AS FirstDayOfQuarter,
DATEADD(qq, DATEDIFF(qq, 0, @today)+0, 0) AS LastDayOfQuarter

output
————
FirstDayOfQuarter LastDayOfQuarter
2004-04-01 00:00:00 2004-07-01 00:00:00
